titleproper.value: Guide to the Frieda Schwenkmeyer Collection on the Henry Street Settlement Strike <num>WAG.147</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-06-18T18:27:51</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Frieda Schwenkmeyer Collection on the Henry Street Settlement Strike

abstract.value: Frieda Schwenkmeyer (1901- ) was a labor organizer from Cincinnati, Ohio. In 1965 the Henry Street Settlement social workers went on strike for over two months, demanding a single bargaining unit encompassing all workers. This collection contains correspondence, flyers, petitions, meeting notes, picket schedules, clippings, and a small amount of financial records.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Henry Street Settlement Strike Records; WAG 147; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown. The accession number 1950.258 is associated with this collection.

The Henry Street Settlement is a social service agency located in the Lower East Side, which was founded by Lillian Wald in 1893. The Settlement provides social services, arts programming and health care to New Yorkers at 17 difference locations. In 1965 the Henry Street Settlement social workers went on strike for over two months, demanding a single bargaining unit encompassing all workers (both permanent staff and special project staff employeed through foundation or government funding).
This collection contains correspondence, flyers, petitions, meeting notes, picket schedules, clippings, and a small amount of financial records.

subject.value: Social workers |x Labor unions |z New York (State) |z New York.
